text:
The SSL howtos are misleading users into configuring mod_ssl using the following directives:

SSLProtocol all
SSLCipherSuite HIGH:MEDIUM

Which is plain wrong for two reasons:
- it allows ssl2
- it enables ADH ciphers

The default configuration is more secure than this one!

While strictly speaking, it does what it says it does : "accepts strong encryption only", end users also care about authentication.

http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.0/ssl/ssl_howto.html
http://httpd.apache.org/docs/trunk/ssl/ssl_howto.html#onlystrong
creator: florent.daigniere-apache@trustmatta.com

text:
To clarify: the correct configuration would be:

SSLProtocol all -SSLv2
SSLCipherSuite HIGH:MEDIUM:!ADH:!NULL

or even:

SSLCipherSuite HIGH:!ADH:!EXPORT56:!EXP:!MD5:!NULL
creator: florent.daigniere-apache@trustmatta.com

text:
I generally use:

SSLProtocol TLSv1 SSLv3
SSLCipherSuite HIGH:!ADH:!MD5

And Paul Querna has suggested
(http://journal.paul.querna.org/articles/2010/07/10/overclocking-mod_ssl/)

SSLCipherSuite RC4-SHA:AES128-SHA:DEFAUT_STUFF_HERE
SSLHonorCipherOrder on

Which will work for 2.3+ and is reasonably fast and secure.
It is also the default in trunk:
https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/httpd/httpd/trunk/docs/conf/extra/httpd-ssl.conf.in

It seems that in my weeding out of outdated information and un-facts, I've
overlooked the ssl_howto, thank you the pointer.

Here is a first attempt at it:
http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&revision=1037224
creator: i.galic@brainsware.org

text:
- SSLProtocol all
- SSLCipherSuite HIGH:MEDIUM
+ SSLProtocol all -SSLv3
+ SSLCipherSuite HIGH:!ADH:!EXP:!MD5:!NULL
Hmm, afaic you made a typo: SSLv2 is insecure, v3 is ok
